channel.title: Java Number Formatter
channel.description:
http://www.rs-resources.com/utilities.html by pplsuqbawlz
Thanks to Taios for hosting!
It converts numbers from octal, decimal, or hexidecimal to the other types via javascript. Also decides which one uses the least chars so your code is tinier?
[b]Known Bugs: [/b]
[ul][li]It seems to fuck up with numbers over 15 digits.[/li] [li]It just says any in cases of a two/more forms matching in digit length.[/li] [li]No negative number support?[/li][/ul]

item.title: Java Number Formatter
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

I do too, I didn’t think about that regex mistake. Haha. Next time I’ll up the patch.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Number Formatter
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

[quote=“Ollie, post:13, topic:18603”][quote author=BobDole81 link=topic=28142.msg327488#msg327488 date=1161191906]
Yup, does that for all values with a “0\d” in it…simple regex mistake.

text.match("(0[0-7]+)") should be text.match("^(0[0-7]+)$")
[/quote]

your too smart for your own liking :([/quote]But I like how smart I am

Nah, thats just a simple overlooking man…regex typically tries to match ANY form of the pattern provided within the string, which is why the script messed up…I just added a ^ and a $, specifying a start and an end… :\

Read full topic

item.title: Java Number Formatter
item.dc:creator: @Ollie Ollie
item.description:
@Ollie wrote:

[quote=“BobDole81, post:12, topic:18603”]Yup, does that for all values with a “0\d” in it…simple regex mistake.

text.match("(0[0-7]+)") should be text.match("^(0[0-7]+)$")[/quote]

your too smart for your own liking

Read full topic

item.title: Java Number Formatter
item.dc:creator: @BobDole81 BobDole81
item.description:
@BobDole81 wrote:

Yup, does that for all values with a “0\d” in it…simple regex mistake.

text.match("(0[0-7]+)") should be text.match("^(0[0-7]+)$")

Read full topic

Octal: 00 Decimal: 0 Hexadecimal: 0x0 Use Decimal form!

item.title: Java Number Formatter
item.dc:creator: @pplsuqbawlz pplsuqbawlz
item.description:
@pplsuqbawlz wrote:

Lol, thanks. I probably could have used some function that already exists in javascript but I had problems finding it so I just wrote my own base converter. Lol feel free to steal the javascript, you can write up to base 36, actually further, just add onto the key string the chars to represent things beyond base 36. Lol, took a tiny bit of thinking.

Read full topic
